title: Are people paid to ask questions on Quora? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you’re asking does Quora pay people to ask question, the answer is essentially no. Though Quora does have bots that generate generic questions like, “What’s the best pizza in Yonkers, NY?” There undoubtedly are staff members who get those generators rolling. So in that sense part of their job is being paid to ask questions. If you’re asking if there are people who are paid from outside Quora to ask questions, then the answer is definitely yes. Quora has both spammers and paid trolls. Quora does have filters. We don’t see what Quora blocks from getting on. We only see what gets through. Quora does depend on users reporting spam and troll questions.  UPDATE: Some months after answering this, Quora started the Partner Program. It’s a pilot program that people have been (randomly?) invited to. They ask questions and are paid a tiny bit if a question generates answers. Partner Program - Frequently Asked Questions The problem for Quora is that there are way more people who want to answer questions than ones who have questions to ask. The purpose of the program, I believe, is to generate the type of questions people ask on Google which will then bring Quora up in a search. If the question has answers. Clicks then bring in revenue. A couple of Top Writers are in the program and reported being paid less than a $.25. Some prolific question generators say they can earn $10 or so. But it takes lots of questions and time to do that. That’s not 1000s of quality questions, though! When they generate a bunch on one topic it clogs up people’s feeds. The program obviously has some kinks to work out! I’ve found it helps to Mute and Block people who keep generating similar questions. I also have The Qure browser plugin (for Chrome and Firefox). It adds the question author’s name to questions in the feed. That makes it easy to spot the annoying question writers so they can be blocked.

If you can’t make sense out of it you are in good company. I would like to join you. Thousands are trying to figure that out. The quality and usefulness of the question does not seem to matter. There is no time and there are no resources to measure the “quality” of a question. So they adopt a simple metric. You bring them money, and they give you a share of it. How much? I don’t know. And they wont tell. I suspect they generously parted with a greater share last year but this year they are tight-fisted. To earn well, a question must be on a trending topic that invites a lot of views and attracts many answers that in turn attract more views on the answer pages that result in advertisers inserting ad impressions. The more the impressions the more the chances that these ads will actually be clicked on. Each click is like a the ring of a cash register for Quora. Quora has fixed a percentage of this ad revenue to be shared with the person who asked the question. While this is easy to understand what is a mystery is how to ask questions that fulfill the above requirements. I have tried all tricks and failed. I now stopped chasing money for questions, and ask about 4 to 6 questions a day and satisfy myself with the dollar or so that I get per day. Quora cannot be enjoyed if one chases money. Hope this answers your question. —

Oh yes - and also some are paying Quora to do so. "What do you think of the 2018 Expensive Car?"... things like that. And let's not even talk about the number of push questions. Shaping political attitudes is advertising too. The latter would be here regardless of what Quora wanted to do... it's what participatory websites (like this and facebook) have that's appealing to marketers. Now, I doubt Quora is paying anyone for questions that aren't ads in disguise... it's not like there's fake nuclear physics questions here, or more arcane areas of certain subjects. But it's easy to tell - I think. Maybe I'm just into language, but you can tell the stereotypical stoner with his friends in a basement (sophomoric), the true cranks (informed but conspiracy-theory-ish), both are certain vernaculars. There's also adult cases of arrested development, another vernacular. Ads seem slightly too well written, have turns of phrase that are more "written" than "spoken" - most people here, I've noticed, write in a kind of spoken in a proper written English way - i.e., they've written college papers, they can construct a paragraph, but there's a person writing it, you can tell. A touch of conversational there. Some are great communicators - the serious stuff that Habib Fanny has written are both academic and accessible. You're not going to see that in ads. They're in ad-speak. They're not going anywhere, though... really, looking at ye olde edit log, seeing if it's anonymous, seeing if the OP seems like a real person... after a while, I wouldn't get worked up over something that seems sketchy. There's a few members I've noticed that, hmmm.... I feel their questions are "placed" but I don't know. Anyways, as another member used to be fond of saying, if you think it's free, it's not. So of course there's money in the background, every business, every website there is. You just have to guard your own intellect from nutters or ads.

Thanks for A2A. Yes, Quora pays me for asking questions on this platform. I’m a member of the Quora Partner Program since January 2019. With the Quora Partner Program, Quora compensate users who make Quora better. As a partner you can earn money by asking questions that many people want answers to and by requesting qualified writers to answer questions. When you add a question to Quora, it's often a question others have too. The more people there are who want answers to questions you add, and the better the answers to these questions , the more you'll earn. You can request answers to questions from qualified writers on Quora, and the more good answers your requests produce, the more you'll earn, all while helping Quora become more useful to others. You get paid as your questions and requests produce useful answers that others discover, either on Quora or elsewhere on the web. You make money from the advertising revenue earned from answers you helped produce because good, useful answers which can help others depend on good, well-considered questions and requests. QPP is an invite-only program and most probably the invite is completely random. You also agree to be bound by the Platform Terms (https://www.quora.com/about/tos) as a condition of participation. Nikhil Lunia

Well…sort of. For starters, you have to be invited to join the Quora Partner Program (or QPP, often hilariously backronymed as the “Quality Prevention Program”) The QPP financially rewards its members for asking “high quality” questions on Quora. At least, in theory. What it really does is reward questions that generate traffic. And as any business person can tell you, you have two strategies for generating revenue: quality, or quantity. Some people in the QPP take the time to write good, insightful questions that really make you think. Others spam Quora with thousands of questions like “What’s the square root of 34?” or “What’s your review of *insert random movie*?”. Now you might be thinking “Who clicks on ‘What’s the square root of 34?’” and the answer is very few people. But if you also post “What’s the square root of 35?” and “What’s the square root of 36?” and so on…it starts to add up. I was invited to join the QPP. I’ve earned all of $9.79 for my question-writing efforts. Not $9.79 per day… $9.79 total. (I believe you can’t cash out until you reach $10) But I refuse to spam Quora with pointless questions, so I don’t think I shall be retiring on my QPP nest egg any time soon. For the record, I’ve read some murmuring lately that people are having trouble getting paid by the QPP, even if they have passed the $10 threshold. Make of that what you will. My point is this: if you’re looking to make money online, there are easier and more reliable ways to do it than the Quora Partner Program.

With a lot of patience and perseverance sprinkled with a generous portion of disappointment and spiced very lightly with an occasional nugget of WTF. You see, when you start out, you have delusions of grandeur, thinking you just need to ask a few questions and earn a few hundred bucks… you’ll very quickly learn this isn’t how it works and you’ll be immensely disappointed to find a vast majority of your questions are worth nothing, or only make a few cents. Getting a question worth hundreds is not unlike winning the lottery, it might happen, but you really can’t rely on it. Most of your revenue will come from those questions that never crack 20 cents. The QPP is, put simply, a numbers game. To make anything even resembling decent money, you’ll need to amass thousands of questions churning out 1–10 cents every other day. The temptation is there to mass produce questions, to churn them out like a program or lift them from a trivia book but everything you do on Quora effects the visibility of your content. Using templates or quiz questions will attract a whole heap of animosity and downvotes, this severely effects the visibility of your content as well as your potential to earn. You might make a quick buck, but you’ll restrict your future potential and possibly get dropped from the program if your questions are too trivial or obvious. If you stick with it though, after a few months you’ll start to make some progress, but it will be slow. If you’re diligent, your question quality will improve, your visibility will be good and you’ll make more per question.

Quora pays only certain users for asking valuable questions and contributing to the platform throgh Quora Partner Program (QPP). It is a completely invite based program which is credited to only few people on Quora who seem to be regular and have complied with the Quora policy. How does QPP work? Through QPP, every partner gets a dashboard (as shown in the image) where they can add question and track their earning. Your earnings are determined by the amount of views and the ads shown/ Clicked.  (Source: Google Images) However, off late I have read that a lot of people have received the invite just in few weeks of joining Quora without having contributed much, while others who have spent a lot of time, are yet deprived. It makes me question if the process is completely random. I got in touch with the Quora team for QPP recently and I asked them the same question to which I was told that QPP will be open for more people in coming days. So, just contribute your best to the platform and wait until Quora thinks you're deserving. You can make use of the platform even without QPP by contributing and learning from plethora of good writers here. QPP is just a bonus! Suggestion: Do not count on it as a reat source of income as it doesn't a pay lot as it did earlier. You might have to spend a lot of time to earn a dime. As pointed out earlier by Gopalkrishna Vishwanath Sir in one of his recent answers that QPP is best for the people who are retired or just stay at home with not much of a responsibility and enjoy sharing their knowledge on this Platform. Hope that helps!

Unfortunately, yes. So now instead of having a site where people who are seeking answers about something that's puzzling them, many, if not most of the 'questions' are in fact just posted to earn money. The result is hundreds of inane questions posted without anyone actually hoping for an answer. Get ready to plow through a hundred "What's the weirdest thing you saw in a bank?", "What's the creepiest thing a dentist told you?", "What's the biggest attraction in Mesa Verde?", "What's the biggest attraction in Quito?", "Is Shreveport dangerous?", "Is Frankfurt dangerous?", "Is Boston dangerous?" type questions. Perhaps you'll be one of the many suckers who supply good-faith written answers, not realizing that these questions were mass-posted by some bot, and there is no one looking to read your reply.Alas.

Have any of you actually gotten paid for questions on Quora? I get paid daily. I could stop asking questions full stop and I'd still make at least $0.30 a day off of old questions that I've submitted (at least until their one-year campaigns are up). It's just peanuts, but it's still better than $0.00. I haven't been making any money off of new questions that I've ever asked or re-asked in about a month or so. I've determined that the only questions that make any money for me are on the topics of pets, politics, WWE, Taylor Swift, Ariana Grande, Michael Jackson and the Beatles. I make next to nothing on anything that falls outside of those categories.

You have to get invited to the QPP, the Quora partner program. To get an invitation I recommend the following: ask 50 quality questions, answer 50 questions. It could be fewer but you will increase your chances dramatically if you do 50/50. Once you get invited to the program you will not be paid per question but instead we paid on what is called revenue sharing. It’s very simple and is very similar to Google ad words or other content networks. You are sometimes paid pennies. It’s not easy money. You have to ask quality questions. That’s how you get paid to ask questions. I will come back and post the explanation of the QPP views, add presentation and clicks so that maybe it would help you understand better. QPP is not a big moneymaker but it can buy you a cup of coffee or more each month depending on how much work you do. The top partner makes about $5000 a month and they work pretty hard. Here’s how to understand QPP and how people are paid: What are "Ad Impressions" on the Quora partner program?

Yes, sort of. IF you get invited to be a Quora Partner by Quora. ARE they still inviting people? - who knows!? But if you get an invite, and don’t stuff up by getting banned - then: When you reach $US5 Quora will ask for your Stripe account details if you live in the US or PayPal account details if you live outside the US. When you reach $US10 you are eligible to be paid. You get this money automatically if you reach the $10 by the first Monday of the Month. The money gets into your Stripe or PayPal account usually within 24 hours. Note however: There is NO guarantee you will get anything from Quora. Quora shares a part of ad revenue they MAY receive from adverts placed under questions. If Quora gets nothing, you get nothing. Earnings since the September algorithm adjustment have been much reduced usually, often to about 1/4th of the amount before hand. So don’t expect to get rich fast on Quora, or even slowly. OP: Can I actually earn money from asking questions on here, and how do I get it?

It’s a pain at the beginning, but yes, you can. But you have to look at it a little bit differently to see if it’s something you want to get into. I went into this whole Partner Program with the mindset that I’m making all these little deposits every day into an interest-based checking account. Just like with one of those, you’re not going to earn that much from the start. But little by little over time, you will start to see your earnings slowly go on the up the more questions you ask, and I mean questions that get a lot of engagement and attention. Just a few days ago, I was only earning 50 cents from a day, and the amount that I’m accumulating daily has already doubled. I see progress each day, and I’m going to continue to keep at this to see what happens. I’ve only been posting questions like this on Quora since last week, but I’m convinced that it’s not only a fun way to learn but a cool way to build a bit of passive income on the side in addition to having a job already. Check it out!  My goal with this is to try to get this up a bit more to the point where I’m earning at least a few dollars a day, but try to keep my questions as high quality as I can. I also still enjoy contributing answers to this site daily.

In theory yes. Due to the quantity (and hopefully quality) of my quora answers, I received an offer to participate in the Quora partner program. There’s only one catch. The program pays you for questions, and answers generated by your questions. It does not pay you for answers you post on other people’s questions. To date, I have answered hundreds of questions on Quora, but I have a asked all of one question. It was before there was a partner program. It didn’t matter anyway. It got zero answers. So, when I look at my Partner Program homepage, I see this:  *Sigh* So no. I am not being paid to ask questions or answer questions on Quora.

You’re already getting paid to ask this question.A message to all those who are a part of the QPP: STOP SPAMMING QUORA. This has been going on, ever since quora invited people to its Quora Partners Program. The questions here have stopped making sense and started bringing up ads and revenue - for Quora and those who put up the questions. End of discussion. For your question, YEAH, people are definitely getting paid for asking the silliest and the most useless questions on quora. I’ll sign off with this example.  Hope this helps. No hate. Cheers.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Vikash Pareek and Ababil Ansari

response.answer_text: You can, if you ask enough questions that provoke meaningful or interesting content, through the Quora Partnership Program. Take me for example. I am on the program and absolutely raking it in!  I think the key is having a steady stream of questions and not doing what I do, which is beginning to ask a question then getting sidetracked by all the suggestions that follow. While I was in the middle of writing this answer, I may have asked a few more questions. Here’s hoping something comes of that and I can one day make it to a full £1!

Well Quora not paying me anything because I’m not participate in their program.. But I list my Forex strategy what I have created to gain profit from trading currency. And every time when I answer questions on Quora some people are interested in my answers and check my profile… Some of them enroll to my strategies as well.. So in total this brings around $800-$1 000… And this is not my main income … it’s just hobby.. bcz I like spending time on Quora when I have free time…Mostly I used that by using their mobile app.

You can make a little money. It’s a lot of work for me though. I have no idea how the real money is made. I’m happy enough with my little bit. And it gives me a tiny place to vent in that none of the people I’m venting about is going to read it. I can strangely enough feel like I have some privacy even though I’m telling the whole world. If you write a lot of questions and some good ones that draw traffic from Quora people and from outsiders you make some money once you become a partner. Good Luck!

You don’t make good money. QPP is not a career, but was intended as a way to get more people to see Quora questions in search engines (and also to share ad revenue) Problem is that people started spamming crappy one line questions. If no one visits your question, no ad revenue is generated and you don’t earn anything. Quora shows that some people make over USD1000 per month, but I haven’t checked their stats. I am willing to bet that they were early Quorians and have thousands of quality questions that cover a broad range of topics and thus get lots of views.

Firstly, you need to be invited into Quora’s ridiculous Partner Programme. Then you have to try to think up some decent, original questions. Before asking a question, type it into the search bar. If it’s been asked before it’s worth $0.0000000001 or nothing at all. To make money your questions have to be viewed, upvoted, and most importantly, ads clicked. Don’t give up your day job..

Thanks for the A2A. If you are a member of the Quora Partner Program a portion of the advertising revenue shown on answers to a question you asked will be shared with you. The Quora Partner Program is an abomination that encourages bottom-feeders to spam-blast the site with cookie-cutter questions, making Quora harder to use for everyone. Most people who are involved in the program don’t even make enough to buy a pizza every month. My advice is don’t bother. For more information, please consult the FAQ on the Quora Partner Program: https://www.quora.com/partners/faq

One gets paid for asking questions on Quora via the Quora Partner Program. It's a top secret program that i invite only and with asking helpful questions and getting “helpful “answers you earn cash depending on how many advertisers want to advertise there. You can get detailed statistics about where the source of the traffic that views the question comes from, and how many ad impressions are on your question so far and have been showed to your fellow Quorans.

Well they sure don’t pay me! And I’d like to think I’m a good questioner and answerer. So maybe they pay somebody on a much higher plane than me, but that’s all I know. Heck, I can even punctuate correctly, including semi-colons, don’t use split infinitives and never ever use a comma with an “and” conjunctive. Please see the New Yorker Magazine style sheet for a definitive guide to good writing. Really; pretty please.

.Why is Quora paying to ask questions? Answer from my previous comment. It's chicken or egg issue. Without questions, there are no answers. Without answers, there are no users. Before QPP, very few people asked questions. Traffic came from Google but not enough to satisfy demand for people who like answering questions or bringing more traffic to QUORA.  SOURCE: Is Quora better than Google for answers?

Yes. It's true, and I'm one of them. I was invited to the Partner Program, and frankly, it's not worth the time. I've been passively using it since it rolled out. When I have an actual question, I ask it. But I don't spam nothings like “what's the weirdest thing you've seen in a bank" because that's garbage, frankly. To date, I've made a staggering $2.13. Woohoo. It is a thing, but it is not worth your time.

No, the program is not royalty to pay you for your questions. It is a revenue-sharing program. If your questions helped Quora to make some revenue from the ads, Quora will share a part of the revenue with you. This is was a very common model 10 years ago for publishing articles in websites such as suite101, examiner, etc. Quora Partner Program is somehow unique as works for questions. As far as I know it is unprecedented. And according to the official blog, it has been quite successful for both sides.

A few things you need to know: You must be a member of the Quora Partner Program;It’s not easy money. It’s difficult and challenging;You must be willing to work for ridiculously low wages for at least 4 months;You really need to be good at it, and love doing it, or desperate;Every day, I get mail from partners saying how much my blog helps them. Therefore, it probably helps to read it. If you FOLLOW it, Quora will send you a notification every time it updates.Jenna Ravenstone Writer, Tips for Quora Partners blog

The quora partnership program earnings vary, currently the top earning partners list says someone earned $3,970.87 this week but someone could earn nothing if their questions aren’t answered or the answers don’t get many views. Quora says the average question value is $0.99 AU but some questions earn over $1000 dollars. I guess the limit is how many answers you can get and how often the answers get viewed.

First, you have to be invited to the Quora Partner Program. This is on an invite-only basis and only in certain countries. You earn money by asking questions which are displayed next to advertisements. The more people that see your question, the more ad impressions you will get, which means more money. Some questions make more than others, so you'll have to do a little experimenting to find good types of questions to ask. Some topics, like Quora, are excluded from this and can't earn money. So start asking questions, it's harder than you think

Most certainly. That’s what marketing experts and growth hackers do for living. Believing there’s zero of them online at the moment is as naive as believing that, say, exactly zero women in San Francisco are drinking in random bars alone with the only hope of getting laid.

That's just it - you simply ask questions, and, if you're part of the Quora Partner Program, you get paid a couple of cents for ad impressions. The best way to make lots of money is to ask tons of questions a day (60+), request 25 people on each question to answer it, repeat those two steps daily (as well as requesting answers on oldrr questions), and you'll be making money a lot faster.

Have you already been approached to join the Quora Partnership Programme? If so, your invite should have told you about linking your bank details to your Quora account, and how often your money will be paid. Money is only paid once a month. If you’ve done that, can see you’ve earned some money but not been paid that, contact Quora directly to see if maybe there’s been an error or mistake made somewhere. If you haven’t been asked to join the programme, your question will earn you nothing. Sorry!

I’m willing to bet that there are definitely a few shills Quora pays to type out generic answers and advice when the interest in the site is low and there aren’t a lot of answers. I mean, I suspect that Quora has an automated process for this already anyways, but that’s just a guess. In any case, it’s not unreasonable to expect that sort of scenario, especially since it’s not illegal.

Yes. You can ask people to click on your website URL for testing purposes. For example, hey guys could you please tell me what you think about the content of my website? Then when people start clicking and giving their opinion you would have increased the traffic. You can have ads on the website. The money you make from such traffic is not a fortune but if you give an incentive and they click on an ad that wins them something then yeah you could make some money.

Q: Are you being paid to ask questions or to answer questions on Quora? Not this little black cormorant. The Quora Partner Program[1], currently in limited release, pays question askers (apparently a small pittance) for their questions. My understanding is that membership of the program is currently by invitation only.  Thanks for the A2A Bernardo. Footnotes[1] Quora Partner Program (QPP)

Did you get paid for asking that question? Unfortunately, since the Quora Partner Program was introduced, that horrible irony is a distinct possibility. * If you’re just a regular person wondering, then the answer is yes, some people do get small payments to ask questions which in turn generate content, as the following link should explain. What is the Quora Partnership Program, and why was I invited to it (*You’re welcome.)

So the answer is yes. I didn’t know this until I read the other answers just now. And no wonder Quora has become unusable. Companies could provide a good website and make a lot of money. Instead they fix on making their websites worse while going for the maximum amount of money. In the long run it damages the website, and perhaps it will no longer be of the worth it originally was.

If you ask quality questions that generate a lot of answers, then yes. You can make money here. I looked at your content. You are clearly a partner program member, asking questions in order to get money, rather than caring about the answers. You are spamming this site in order to earn a few cents. So, I muted you, which means I don’t have to see your questions at all. And a lot of others will mute you, as well. So, I doubt you are going to earn much here. “Coming up” with low quality questions that only clog the site is not what the partner program is supposed to be.

Before asking questions and earning from them, please consider: One should have thousands of followers on their profileThen they should get an invitation from the qpp.Then when one starts to earn, it is not a substantial amount.One should never forget that businesses don't create programs for others to earn enough to live just with it but the plans are prepared for the businesses to prosper.All the best.

So far we are aware there are no people paid to specificly ask questions, although it is known that Quora employs bots to generate questions for the site/app. If the generated questions get published automaticly or are handlicked however is unknown to us. So the closest you could get to being paid for asking questions is being a software engineer at quora that maintains the bots for questions.

Yes you can make money on quora but it's really only bubblegum money. There is so much more to it though. It's a heck of a lot better than Google. You can ask a question and get answers from professionals. These are real life experiences and skills that can be shared. I have gotten a tremendous amount of advice using quora . When I try using Google I get a plethora of bad advice, advertisements and YouTube videos that I'm not interested in. There are a ton of professionals in a variety of companies and so many people with various education levels and they all have so much knowledge much to offer. I appreciate every one of them!

The Quora Partner Program does devalue questions. It devalues them because it increases the number of questions asked. That means those people who genuinely want to know something are less likely to get their questions answered, lost to questions designed to tie up the attention of others. I answer fewer questions because of the time I spend downvoting abusive questions, and Muting people asking thousands of stupid ones.

You get paid once you get lots of views for every question that you ask and if you get enough views for every question and everything or if you get enough followers eventually Quora will send you an email and they will ask you to be a Quora affiliate I believe and once that happens you will start getting paid for that depending on what yo worked out with them.

Though it is an answer, you can use your answer to sell your skill set, market your website etc etc. People in trading, education are all over the place in Quora with each one trying to prove to their competition why they are better. So the better you answer more people would buy your pitch. I have myself bought an educational pack based on Quora answers.

I think you can if you ask people to donate to a great cause. People go on crowdfunding to do this. I believe you can do the same here. Today, most people are comfortable to donate online. You can read more about this online donation from this article: Making Money From The Website. Part of this article discusses about online donation. This will give you some good info.

Yes, you can through Quora Partner Program. They pay you for asking questions. There's no fixed rates or anything. It's just that the more ad impressions the answers on your questions get, the more you'll make from your account. Here is a glimpse:  To apply to the Quora partner program, go to quora.com/partners and request them to invite you for the program.

Personally, I am not. However, if you were to answer a number of questions and ask other questions that people commonly have, than Quora would send you an email about the Partnership Program. In this program, you can earn money simply by asking and answering questions. I have gotten this offer before, but have not chosen to pursue it.

There are a few conditions to be followed the get paid. Your question should be more popular.It should contain more impression.It should not be asked earlier by anyone else.The more views you will get, the more amount you will be paid.Quora will pay you the money through your PayPal account into your bank.To get the money your earning should be more than 10$.

A2A. No. In my 3+ years here, I’ve Asked 12 Questions. I abhor the practice of paying people to write Questions, and am re-examining whether I want to support such a thing with my freely given Answers. I Mute and Block people who only ask questions. Goodbye, Bernardo Marcial .

No, they don’t. There is the Quora Partner Program, which gives you a share of the ad revenue that Quora earns from the ads displayed on people’s questions. But that’s it. And for the most part earnings are extremely small. I earned $30 last month and that’s relatively high - it’s unusual I get as much as a dollar a day.

Yes, you can. It’s not a huge amount. You have to be invited by Quora to join their Partner Program. You’ll have the choice to join or decline. When you join they’ll send you a link to create a stripe account. Your stripe account is where you add your banking informations so that you receive payments. You get a deposit once a month. Usually within the first week of every month. And yes all you have to do is ask questions, the questions have to get answers and views to generate money. I started the program mid May and this is my earnings so far.

You can maybe add links to your own personal services at the end of your useful questions, but be careful you don’t get reported for spamming. Otherwise YOU DON’T make money through quora, or Y!A, or any other public Q&A site. (don’t even know why people would think you would/could)

No I don’t. I don’t participate in Quora Partner Programs. But, yes, you can earn money asking question in Quora. Quora paid from the advertising revenue share with the asker. I don’t know why they don’t pay for the people giving answer though.

If you want to start earning money from Quora you will have to be frequent towards Quora . Quora doesn't gives money instantly , after verifying your account they will sent an invitation as a Quora programm partner . According to me , these are the points which you should remember. 1.You should spend more time on Quora 2.Regular answering questions will give good effect on ur account. 3.Timing of invitation depends on your accounts flexibility . 4.Your way of writing should be good so that readers easily get your point. AND YES , YOU CAN DEFINITELY EARN ON QUORA BY ASKING QUESTIONS!!!

I do, but so little it makes little difference. maybe I ask more questions than I did before in the hope of hitting the occasional advertising jackpot- but it hasn’t happened yet. The nature of my questions remains the same and I’m certainly not in the business of generating click bait!

By asking questions that drive traffic to the site and which allow Quora to serve advertisments. Also — how many freaking times will this same question be asked with slightly different wording? Check out the search function, it’s really cool, I promise.

I would suggest you to look at their policy on partner program or ask some top questioner. They may explain. I actually don't know. They invited me to the partner program. I didn't accept. I am good at answering questions. Not asking. So, I didn't join. Also, my intentions were to showcase my spiritual gifts. For that I have to answer, not ask. So, I have actually no clue. All the very best! Regards, Swaroopa.

Yes but you need to be invited into the Quora partner program. You can increase the chance of this happening by writing answers and asking questions on the platform more regularly. You can also earn money by answering questions and directing links to relevant content. So if you have a blog, you’re allowed to link to some of your content if it’s relevant to the answers you give. You also need to give content in your answer, rather than just putting a link.

Yes. It's a thing called Quora Partner Program. You're payed to ask questions (like 2 cents apiece). The more attention it gets, the more money you earn. Unfortunately, some people take full advantage and spam low quality questions. For example: What is the name of a fruit that doesn't have <letter>, <letter>, and <letter>? You've probably seen one of those before. The Partner proceeds to swap with every letter in the alphabet with different combinations. What do you get? Hundreds of cookie cutter questions to earn money from.

Quora pays people to ask questions via the Partner Program. If you want to make a living answering questions, you may want to move to Medium.com. At this time, I have not yet received an invitation from the Partner Program.

You will be paid for asking questions here, if you are included in Quora Partner Program and if you conform to its terms and conditions.  Thanking Jai Sharma for the query — Will I get paid for asking questions on Quora? Good luck:-)

Questions don’t belong to the asker. This is very clear in Quora’s Terms of Service. All questions are donations to the site (some of them with some kick back to the asker), so the motivations of the asker are immaterial. If the question is one that someone might have, and it’s answerable, it’s allowed on Quora.

I did get in on earning with Quora but by invitation with pay to Stripe. You need to focus your time posting good content on Quora. Then you might get noticed by Quora. I spend most of my time at work from 7 am to 3:30 pm weekdays and it is hard to post long answers on a phone.

You could technically make some money off of Quora, but I don’t believe it is enough to support yourself. If you want to really be successful, I suggest going out and finding a good job. It definitely will be worth it.

You need three things. Time to ask questions.Ask unique and thought-provoking questions.Find the best person to answer your questions and ask them to answer it.To Jenna Ravenstone point. Earning money on QPP is not easy money. It requires a lot of time and effort.

There’s Quora’s partner program if you get invited to it, and become a Quora partner, Then you can earn by asking questions here. There might be guidelines as to how many views you might have on your questions so that you can score an invite to the partner program. I hope this answer helps you, Have a good day.

Yes, like anywhere that has a prevalent community, there will be marketing and advertising. How do you get more money asking questions on Quora? If what you’ve been doing has earned you one dollar, then doubling your effort will earn you two dollars, and so on.

Write creative answers with meaningful links or build your brand via referral links. All of those will create more opportunity for you make money but indirectly.

If you get invited to the Quora Partner Program, you get a portion of the ad revenue Quora earns from ads on your questions.

As a question is answered it gains momentum up to a year. The more it is viewed the more revenue you can potentially earn for quora, in turn you share a small portion because you asked the question to be answered.
